hi and welcome to our presentation the mass effect how opportunistic workers drift into cyber crime i'm massah paket
klusten from go secure and i'm sergio lucia parquet from secureworks and we also want to thank sebastian
garcia from the stratosphere laboratory as well as machia jose jaga from cisco system who both have participated in the
research so today what we're doing is we are presenting our research journey that
goes from studying but masters or at least we thought all the way up to uncovering an informal economy involved
or potentially involved in cyber crime and we also thought it was a very good opportunity to present three research
techniques that we believe are unusual in the field of cyber security research
but could be beneficial for other projects so let's jump into the background and
how this research came alive so it all started a few years ago when the stratosphere
laboratory uncovered the geospatnet while monitoring the htbot proxy malware
what is geos well it's an android banking trojan button targeting mainly russian citizens
it has infected over 800 000 russian phones and also was estimated to have made millions of
dollars if you have any questions related to gs infrastructure cnc panels and all that
you can look online there has there are two really good presentations one from virus bolton the other one from black
hat europe done by the stratosphere laboratory what is of interest today is while doing that
investigation veronica valeros found a chat log on virustotal that contain
private discussions among individuals involved at spreading the buttnet so this really triggered
this research that we're presenting today so this private chat log between people
uh directly involved into spreading malware was a very very unique opportunity because very seldom can we
assess first-hand conversation between people spreading malware so this chat log is a skype leak
of about 6000 messages that spreads from between 2017
and 2018 for about 11 months and it's between 32 individuals
so we know they were discussing gist because they were exchanging key information
about the cnc internal commands ip addresses and domains as well as some freshly infected apks
that they shared among themselves so the conversations are in russian and they were translated by a security researcher
named ana shurikova which is also russian speaking
and in the conversations there are 32 individuals but only three important the
three main important ones an entrepreneur a developer and a webmaster and we want
you to remember them because they're going to come later in the presentation now the very interesting thing is that
in this con in this chat log they were also mentioning conversations that happen on a public space
and very really rarely do we have information on private discussions as
well as public ones so we pivoted to understanding what they were discussing on a public forum called
search engines.guru which has over half a million users
this specific forum is a russian-speaking internet marketing platform and all the users discussing on
it we're kind of considered like an informal workforce as you're gonna see in a little bit
so this presentation is divided in five large themes that we called acts and
we're gonna go over each of them in the next 30 minutes so the first
act that we're going to see is called an informal workforce and we're going to investigate what is the forum and a
little bit what what are people discussing on it so the forum has advertised on its
homepage is a website allowing users to discuss issues related to creating and promoting
websites on the internet so on the surface everything's look looks clean so the forum has been alive
for the last 20 years or so um and has more than 400 000 users registered
and all in all there has been more than 14 million polls for the span of the 20 years
as you can see from the graph here uh the peak of the of the forum use was
in 2010 and has since been in slow decline so there could be many reasons for this
one of them being that the whole field of internet marketing and web marketing
has become more difficult over the years mainly because of various protections
and security measures from the search engines notice also in the timeline that we added the specific time frame when the
chat log the individuals in the private chat log were active so in 2017 and 2018
and we also plotted the first known gis activity and the last non-gs activity
which is 2016 and the end of 2019. now it's important to mention that all
the data that we're presenting today that we used from this forum but although also many others was possible
because we had an academic access to the flare systems database so flair system is a startup based in montreal that does
darknet monitoring platform and also monitoring of all other kinds of platforms on the clearweb so we want to
thank them and then mention their collaboration in the research so what do people talk about on
this informal space so um the the forum is divided in nine main
categories uh each of them being developed in subcategories with various amount of posts
so the categories are such as how to monetize websites how to build websites
and very various services and exchanges for webmasters as well as how to optimize search engine
when you look at the categories nothing looks shady and obviously let's not lie
to ourselves like internet marketing is usually related to shady activities somehow
sometimes so when you look at the subcategories you kind of get hints by one category
that some dubious activities are happening on the platform so the category doorways and cloaking
definitely refers to black hat seo and thus you know manipulating user into
clicking on links that they wouldn't want to click on but we're still light years away from uh operating or or
being the mastermind behind a large-scale botnet so looking at this it
kind of inspired us to talk about informal economies so what do we refer by that
is all income earning activities that are not regulated by the state an economic environment where such
activities would usually be regulated so you can think of many examples that people are familiar with a waiter that
wouldn't declare a hundred percent of its tip for example or people who sell goods on ttg and ebay
well there is an amount after which you should be declaring revenues and pay taxes what happens if you don't
so what it it's important to know it it's not the product or the service that it is illegal it is rather the means by
which it is produced or distributed that is so given uh this information the
question that we asked ourselves is how can we get a quick understanding of the users
of the forum or can we map the forum users to grasp their behavior
so fortunately there is a set of techniques in machine learning that maybe will help to do so so that will be
the first technique we're going to see so first of all thanks again to the flare database
we collected the data from each post for the years of 2017 and 2018. so for
two years and in this data we have the username the topic the content category
subcategory and the date and so on so forth in order to do machine learning what we need is a numerical representation of
the users and what we mean by that well the numerical representation is basically a vector of number
so we constructed the fingerprint of the users by just summing over the span of
the two years the categories in which the user has posted that would give us
a user like a unit of user now what we did is that we
did this for each of the users that were present in the forum for these two years and that would give us a big matrix we
just see a little glimpse here that would give us a very very big matrix and we want to make sense out of this so to
be able to see if there are patterns in the users so basically what we want is a map of
the forum based on the users with 2d representation
now there exists a techniques that it does exactly this it's called umap and it was developed by leland makiness and
john healy from the tuft institute and they were very kind to help us get a better grasp of what's
going on under the hood so basically what um does is that it takes the data in high dimension in this
case it would be each point would be a user in nine dimension nine being the number of categories
and then from this space it would create a graph and the graph
the nodes would be the users and they would be connected if they are nearest neighbors in some specific
kind of way and then from this graph in nine dimension it would just project it in two dimensions
in the plane and then untangle the graph using some clever algorithms in order to
preserve this relationship this distance nearest neighbor relationship now i put
a lot of details under the rug but the code is very simple to use and the documentation is very good and you can
find it online it's open source so we did exactly this with our users
and we projected them on a 2d map and we get the map so this is a representation of
the forum users and even though it looks like a mess it's filled with information so bear with me
first of all the x and y axis don't mean anything they are not interpretable in the umap embedding so we just removed it
what matters is the relationship between the points so users who have similar posting behaviors will be closed
together in the map now what we see here is that there are nine arms
interestingly enough these arms represent categories in the forum so really the clusters that we see are
groups of users who post mainly in one category so on average more in the category but another thing is preserved
is the magnitude of the phenomenon so how much they post so users who are at the outer edge of
the arms are users who post more on average than users who are closer to the center now a little higher level of
structure we see that there are two arms on the right and the rest of the arms on the left and the two arms on the right
are close together and also short in length meaning that users in these categories are probably
not so passionate or they don't post as much as in the other categories remember earlier we talked about the private chat
log in three individuals who were forming the bulk of the conversations where since they were these individuals
discussing on the forum too we you may be wondering where are they situated on the map
well we map them and we see that they are much more at the center of the map than at the outer edge
of arms so it looks like these individuals could be more opportunistic or speaking less
than other individuals who would be more passionate about their topics so really this
relationship of maybe looking opportunistic was really interesting to us so we asked
the question is this the case so what kind of business are they
actually involved in well fortunately we have the chat log okay so this leads us to our second act
dancing on the crime line and you're soon going to see why we called it that way so we talked about chat log earlier you
remember 6000 messages well it was formed of one entrepreneur and 32
of his business partners as we mentioned however two of them formed the bulk of the conversation
hence there was three individuals that were key in the private chat look you may be wondering what they were
doing well they were developing android portals to be able to spread infected
apks so we gave you we took a screenshot of one of their websites so you can have an
idea of what it looks like it's basically just websites where you go on and you download applications that
would have special features such as better so we took a screenshot of the website
so you could have a better idea of what it looks like and as you can see you just go on the website and you can
download various apks that have special features maybe unlock features as well if you
went on this website in 2017 or in 2018 you would have most likely downloaded a
geos apk which means that the application icon would have disappeared
you would have thought that the application installation just didn't work and your phone would be infected
with a banking trojan so what we did with the private jet lag is automatic analysis this is another
method that we wanted to present it's really used in criminology and in social
science to extract meaning out of textual data so what you do is you read the text and
you find teams associated to the text and then you do this over and over again
so we did this and we ended up with three teams which we want to present today
the first theme is adverse business environment so there was no doubt that these individuals were
facing unreliable business partners unstable payments declining business prospects and low profitability so given
the uniqueness of this data set this presentation would be very sad and a bit
boring if we didn't go into the conversation and show you some simple so here we go
so for example in october 2017 the webmaster tells to the entrepreneur well
there's nothing you can do you should always be prepared this business is not stable hence the idea of adverse business
environments and then the same character says over and over again to the entrepreneur that he has trouble getting the money any
news about the money they will not give the money yet did they send the money so you see that this person has trouble
getting paid hence really it enforces the idea of adversity the second team was amateur work
so these individuals seem to be lacking technical skills as well as working with
and building defective tools so again let's jump into the the conversations and see some examples
so the developer in 2017 says that the sites are not high quality that they will not last long and i mean
this is a developer acknowledging his lack of expertise and then the entrepreneur in november
of the same year says that he doesn't know how to split the traffic so they have trouble getting by and constructing
their infrastructure and then our third team was leniency towards criminality which kind of links
back to our second act dancing on the crime line so these guys they were definitely
involved in shady activities and being aware of it they were constantly fighting security measures and all of
that to seek economic independence so again in november 2017 a new
character the affiliate marketer talks about the conversion rate and how
they are different but there is no guarantee that the sun will be better than from legal
hence acknowledging that uh being illegal pays more than being legal and
in a very interesting piece of conversation between the entrepreneur and the webmaster the entrepreneur tells
the other character to try to recrypt and install and in this context recrypt means
obfuscating such that the apk is not being flagged by a security tools
so these three teams kind of encompasses most of the discussions that these individuals had within the private chat
log if there is one kind of big key takeaway is definitely they were not the butt
masters or the motivated offender behind the geospatnet but they seemed rather to
be those individuals at the periphery of their criminal scheme helping for the infected apks to spread
in the wild so given that we know now what they're doing or what they talked about in their
private conversations let's go and look at what they're doing on the forum in the public space
so what we did is we gathered information on the three individuals who spoke also on the public forum
and the first thing we asked was who are they talking to right so we used a map
and colored each of the individuals that were in the same thread as the
entrepreneur the webmaster and the developer and as you can see although there's a small cluster in the middle well they
seem to be interacting with people who are positioned everywhere in the forum the second thing that we did is we
wanted to assess qualitatively what they're talking about so we read each of their interactions that represents about
2000 interactions we thank maria for doing this it was very hard work
just trying to comprehend the meaning and what we ended up finding though is well they use the forum to help develop
their android website and they try to find business partners uh through you know interacting with
other forum users and what's really striking here is that never in their public interactions did
they mention geos or spreading any kind of malware even though a lot of these business
interactions were about creating these these infected portals
and that's that's very interesting because it was covertly displayed
in a public space so of course it triggered to us the
question is this dance between criminality and informality come in place is this a
large-scale phenomenon so from there we kind of change scale so our goal was to
assess whether the forum which we conceptualized as an informal space had users who would also be involved in
potentially cyber crime activities and to do that we developed a concept called drifters
drifters are informal workers or more specifically forum users who also
participate in the cybercrime forums so our goal here was to find
a measure of the number of drifters on the forum so people who both speak on
the forum and also in more criminally prone platform and by criminally prone we mean
platform that acknowledge and that publicly state that they are spaces to
share cyber crime information so they embody the criminal ethos
so we use a technique called username matching because there are researches
that state that people tend to reuse their user names
between different platforms so basically you can think of
nicknames in infosec which are very common things people tend to reuse them
so in order to because of course the technique is not perfect there will be false positives and there will be people
who change their name because it's a choice of the user
uh we decided to increase the entropy of the username that we sample in order to do this analysis and increasing the
entropy has the advantage of reducing the number of false positives and avoiding us to
look into each of the conversations to make sure that they are exactly the same users
and so in order to uh to increase this entropy which we chose usernames that were at least five characters long
add an uppercase a number or a special character so that would constitute our sample on
the informal platform and then we use the flair database so we searched for these specific username in the flair
database and checked in which platforms these users were speaking and we had to
develop another filter because when we searched for a specific username in the flair systems then we get all of
their comments on other platforms but these comments can date back a long time ago so we decided to only keep comments
that happened two or plus two or minus years of the private chat log that was in 2017
and 2018. so the comments spanned from 2015 to the end of 2020. so using these two filters
the time frame and the username what we got is out of the flair database
are 38 platforms 17 of them being on the clearweb 21 being on the dark web and it's important
to emphasize that each of these platforms even the one on the clear web are platforms that openly advertise
themselves as criminal spaces so so spaces to share criminal information
now the most common of these you can think of not the theo dark money best hack forum exploit that iron black
at world club to cred which are all related to either cyber crime or stealing information so out of this
whole filtering process we ended up finding 1500 drifters out of the 21 000
users that fitted the filter this represents about 7.2 percent of the whole forum population and we map them
on our form map and as you can see these drifters i can't are kind of placed all over in the
forum so since that seemed to be uh there doesn't seem to be any pattern
as statisticians and data scientists we asked ourselves where there must be some way to differentiate the drifters from
denominators so we asked the question are there characteristics to identify them on the
firm are they special do they form a specific group so we devised a sequence of variables
that we thought could help us to discriminate them so maybe it would be different for the drifters and the non-drifters for
example the activity rate the diversification level various keywords for potential business
interactions or specialized topics now since these variables were far from being gaussian or normal
we couldn't use its traditional statistical test so we use man whitney u test which are
tests that do not assume anything from the underlying distribution they just use the rank instead of the direct value
so just the detail so on the next slide we're going to present you 16 of the variables that we devised
and don't waste time reading the titles what matters is the shape of the distribution
so again i'm stopping you don't try to read the titles get the overall picture so in pale blue you have the drifters
and in purple you have the the non-drifters so the rest of the population anyway what we can see here
is that the the samples are the same so the shape of the distribution is the same
whatever the group now for the statistical test when there was statistical significance to
distinguish the effect size was very very small it was negligible so from this data
it's not possible to distinguish them based on the variables that we devised so what can we conclude from this well
it seems like drifters and nun drifters are indistinguishable at least based on the discriminatory variables that we
could think of and this leads us to conclude that probably the drifter population is
larger than seven percent and thus there are many drifters that are within our non-drifter sample kind of hindering the
analysis and the results and it even stresses that this is most likely a
lower bound right and there are much more and now that we know that there's an
overlap you know between criminally prone spaces and the forum that we studied the next question that we
wondered or that we asked was well is there a relationship between informality and criminality over time or do we see
individuals speaking in the informal forum and then slowly moving out to more criminally prone platforms through time
so this leads us to our four fourth act migration where we want to assess this you know
pattern in time and how did we do this well we developed a migration measure but
okay and to do this we developed a migration measure based on the ei ratio which is a really
widely used measure in social network science ei stands for external internal
in our research external means a person who would be posting on cyber crime platforms and internal means the person
who would be posting on the informal platform and what we want to assess is the ratio of external against internal
platforms posting over every year so if a person scores one in the ei
ratio it means that the person has perfectly migrated and thus is only speaking on cyber crime platform if the
person scores zero it means that there is a perfect balance in the person's post so it the person posts equally on a
cybercrime platform and the informal platform and if the person scores minus
one it means there's no migration at all and the person is only speaking on the form
and what we did is we calculated the ei ratio for all drifters
that were active in from 2012 to 2020 so for every of these years and then we
mapped every user's trajectory so here you have an example of two users
you can see that they go from these two users they go from the informal platform speaking only on
this and then in 2016 they kind of drift and they speak only on cyber crime
platforms this is great we see two users and it's easy to see kind of the drifting the migration
but what happens if we have let's say a thousand trajectories what can you do how can you find pattern
so we asked this question how can we find patterns how could how can we cluster groups of users based on their
drifting pattern so thankfully there exists a family of technique in data science well a lot of techniques
in data science to do so one of them being the group based trajectory modeling which is an instantiation of a
finite mixture model we're gonna see what we mean so first let's introduce some a bit of
statistical terminology so a latent explanatory variable is a variable that's important
that you cannot observe directly from the data you rather have to infer it through analysis so true inferential
analysis in our case this latent variable would be the number of groups so really how to
segment the users so the first step in this group-based trajectory modeling is to determine the good number of group
and we're going to see what we mean by good and then a mixture model as in finite
mixture model is a model in which the total variability that you observe so that the total effect is rather the
result of subgroups or subpopulations so in our case it would really be the
clusters of similar users so each of them have the same variability they have the same pattern but when you observe
everything you see the whole thing so the second step would be to determine
determine the shape of each of these distributions for the groups and by shape we mean are they doing like this
like a sigmoid are they moving quadratically or linearly do we determine this shape
and then the last step is given the these finite models
given these sub models we need to find the best shape so the best parameters for the
shape given the data so we use a technique called maximum likelihood that will maximize the probability of
observing the data given the the model and then you may be wondering how do we find the best model
well we repeat this over and over again trying different numbers of groups and different shapes
in the trajectories of the groups and we try to minimize the patient information criterion while doing this and without
the dot throughout our whole analysis the best model for us was a three group model
hence like presented here what you can see is we have two trajectories combined together they
represent 25 of the population and they both drift from the forum all the way to cyber crime
platforms through time there is also one additional trajectory
the blue one it represents near 75 of the population and what you
can see is it's quite flat so this trajectory illustrates that 75 of the
population will tend to stay within the forum through time
so the next natural thing to do of course was to plot these users on the
map so here it is and as you can see again unsurprisingly there doesn't seem to be
a very strong pattern or a very strong cluster there might be more users toward
the center uh maybe meaning that these users don't have a very strong allegiance and that's
something we could already infer from their location on the map but other than this
they seem to be placed all over the forum there are about 75 of drifters who
will favor informality over cybercrime platforms and about 25 percent who seem
to drift permanently so posting on the informal platform and then slowly moving
to posting more on cybercrime platforms what we can conclude from this is well
it seems like most drifters are criminal curious and we coined that term to refer
to these individuals who will mainly post on the informal platform and based on their posting
pattern we'll post a little bit in cyber crime ones but they will do it really minimally so they will favor staying in
the informal space so then we wanted to generalize uh is is this concerning and
if it is to what extent is this so that would uh trigger our last act
the mass effect by mass effect we don't mean any references to the very successful video
game frenchies what what we refer to is a term in medicine
in which a growing mass a tumor is growing as to push its surrounding
and then pushing the tissues and the organs around it hence increasing the initial problem scale so creating a
ripple effect in the body and we thought it was a good analogy because if the malware industry like
motivated offender trying to spread a butt net for example is growing well there is a large
informal workforce surrounding it that it maybe get hooked to it after a while
so in order to get get a little bit of understanding of of the scale of this problem we collected data from other
similar platform as the forum so here here they are and we just sum their advertised number of users
and apply the same type lower bounds or the same seven percent and that would give us 500 000 individuals that would be
criminal curious and it doesn't matter whether we say five hundred thousand or a million or two million what we want to
say at least is there is a mass there are people who are ready to work
and this is what matters right so what we conclude from our analysis is
there is a large informal workforce evolving at the periphery of the malware industry that is necessary to to its
operation so the individuals that we studied in the private chat log they were not the motivated offender they
were not the people behind geos but they were rather these individuals like the workforce surrounding it
allowing the geos operators to spread their infected apks
and these surrounding individuals we believe well they may or may contribute i mean
think of the second act with dancing on the crime line but based on our findings and like you
know studying the informality and criminality relationship over time we believe that
they would probably rather not and it means that there are possibilities to
maybe avoid them drifting into some cyber criminal activities by for example changing their opportunistic landscape
so how do we conclude what is the key takeaway from this presentation well we think that there is a need to dig
further on the mass effect and the role of informal economies where drifters are dancing on the crime line at the
periphery of the cyber crime industry and more importantly start thinking
beyond the concept of motivated offender our research what it shows is most
people or lots of people involved in cyber crime will not necessarily even be aware of it or will
do it but not as motivated offenders developing the very sophisticated scheme
so by using concepts like we developed in this research mass effect drifters
informal economies we can kind of bring more nuance to the narrative and
potentially a better understanding of the complex phenomenon that is at play right now and as a take out or something
to bring home we also thought that the three techniques we presented the umap
the qualitative thematic analysis and the group based trajectory modeling we think they can be used in other research
so if you have any question feel free to ask us it will be a pleasure to explain in more details how they work and as a
